text:
DNA Studio is a multidisciplinary design company implementing innovative solutions in the fields of urban planning, architecture and interior design. Founded by Nikol Kirova in 2019, the studio is based in Vidin, Bulgaria but operates nationally and worldwide.

Specialized in advanced computationally aided design, the studio offers a range of services from interior and interaction design to parametric architectural solutions and from building information modeling to urban planning. DNA provides custom services to leverage existing solutions and support the digital transformation of the interior and architectural design through 3D scanning and a parametric workflow.

In DNA Studio we use specialized tools for 3D Scanning, digital measurements, point cloud segmentation, computational analysis and immersive digital visualisations. We explore sustainable solutions inspired by the local context and material optimisation strategies to develop cost-effective proposals. This makes it possible to produce fast, data-informed iterations of each proposal. Our aim is to find optimum solutions that serve both the performative aspects of the design as well as the specific needs and preferences of each client.

items.name: NIKOL KIROVA
items.title: architect
items.text:
Nikol Kirova is an interdisciplinary Bulgarian architect with an educational background in interior design, urban planning and advanced architecture. Currently, she is a PhD student in the offshore program of the Swinburne University of Technology. The focus of her research is the integration of material innovation in design and architecture. Nikol is also a teaching assistant and a researcher in IAAC (Institute for Advanced Architecture of Catalonia).

 During the past few years, she has gotten involved in a wide range of projects from material systems to urban interventions. The common feature among her work is the search for alternative solutions for optimised construction, material informed design and spatial communication. Her research interest lies in investigating how materiality in architecture and construction can be reestablished and propose a better communication between the built environment and its inhabitants. 

 For a couple of years Nikol was developing Synapse, a smart material system for real-time urban flow data collection toward responsive environments and informed decision making. The novel research was awarded the Digital Matter and Intelligent Construction excellence award and later with the Artificially and Materially Intelligent Architecture excellence award in 2018 and 2019. 

 During the summer of 2018, she was a physical computing assistant in the Global Summer School in Barcelona and since then she has been assisting in various seminars in IAAC. In the autumn of 2018, Nikol became part of the Norman Foster Foundation after participation in the Robotics Atelier led by Fabio Gramazio. Most recently her work has been recognized as she was selected among many graduates from all over the world to be part of the Antenna program during the Dutch Design Week 2019.
